header.title: The Goetia of Solomon the King

central_thesis: This edition of the Goetia presents a practical system for the evocation and command of 72 infernal spirits (demons) as outlined in the traditional grimoire attributed to King Solomon. Aleister Crowley's unique 'Initiated Interpretation' overlays a psychological and materialistic framework, positing that these 'spirits' are aspects of the magician's own brain or subconscious faculties, and the elaborate rituals serve as methods to stimulate and direct these internal energies for personal development and objective results.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces Crowley's edition of the Goetia, acknowledging its translation by 'G.H. Fra. D.D.C.F.' (S.L. MacGregor Mathers) and his own role as editor and commentator. Crowley criticizes other occultists like A.E. Waite and outlines his 'Initiated Interpretation,' which rationalizes magical phenomena as brain-changes and spirits as portions of the human brain, accessible through ritualistic stimuli.

Features the 'Bornless One' invocation in Greek and Enochian, a powerful opening ritual intended to establish the magician's authority. This invocation asserts the magician's identity with the divine forces of creation and destruction, setting the stage for the commanding of spirits by invoking names of power and affirming control over the elements and various spiritual realms.

structure_content.chapter_title: Defining Magic and the Lemegeton System
structure_content.summary: Provides a 'Preliminary Definition of Magic' as the 'Highest, most Absolute, and most Divine Knowledge of Natural Philosophy.' It distinguishes natural magic from 'Diabolical' practices and outlines the five books of the Lemegeton: Goetia (Evil Spirits), Theurgia-Goetia (Mixed Spirits), Ars Paulina (Planetary Angels), Ars Almadel (Chief Spirits governing Altitudes), and Ars Nova/Notoria (Prayers and Divine Notes). This edition focuses solely on the Goetia.

The core of the grimoire, detailing 72 infernal spirits. Each entry describes the spirit's name, rank (King, Duke, Marquis, President, Earl, Knight), typical appearance, specific offices (e.g., teaching arts, causing love, revealing treasures), number of legions commanded, and unique sigil ('Seal or Character') for summoning and control. It also notes various astrological and Qabalistic attributions, including Hebrew names for the spirits.

Detailed instructions for constructing the essential magical equipment. This includes the 'Magical Circle' (a protective boundary inscribed with divine names and symbols), the 'Magical Triangle of Solomon' (where the spirit is compelled to appear), the 'Hexagram of Solomon,' the 'Pentagram of Solomon,' the 'Magic Ring or Disc of Solomon,' and the 'Vessel of Brass' (for binding spirits). Specifications for materials, dimensions, inscriptions, and colors are provided, emphasizing their symbolic and operative significance.

Outlines the precise verbal commands and ritual procedures for compelling spirits. This includes multiple escalating 'Conjurations' (First, Second, and The Constraint) that use divine names, threats of binding, and curses (Conjuration of the Fire, The Greater Curse) to force appearance and obedience. Upon appearance, the magician gives an 'Address' and 'Welcome,' followed by specific requests, and finally, a 'Licence to Depart,' ensuring the spirit leaves peacefully.

Contains an 'Explanation of Certain Names' used in the Lemegeton, providing Qabalistic and esoteric interpretations for divine names invoked during rituals. This section also offers additional editorial notes, historical context, and corrections regarding the text's sources, transcription errors, and cross-references to other occult works, enriching the practical instructions with deeper meaning and scholarly insight.

key_concepts.definition: The practice of ceremonial magic focused on the evocation and command of 72 specific infernal spirits (demons), as detailed in the first book of the Lemegeton, attributed to King Solomon.

A foundational grimoire in Western Esotericism, also known as 'The Lesser Key of Solomon,' traditionally divided into five books, each concerning a different aspect of magic (Goetia, Theurgia-Goetia, Ars Paulina, Ars Almadel, Ars Nova/Notoria).

In this context, it refers to the 72 distinct spirits listed in the Goetia, derived from a Qabalistic tradition relating to a 72-fold division of the Divine Name, implying a structured hierarchy of spiritual entities.

Unique graphic symbols or characters specific to each Goetic spirit. These are crucial magical tools used for identification, compelling, and binding the spirits, often inscribed on parchment or metal as talismans.

A primary protective ritual space, typically 9 feet in diameter, inscribed with divine names, Hebrew letters, and symbols, designed to safeguard the magician from the invoked spirits. It represents the boundaries of the sacred space and the magician's authority.

A secondary ritual space, placed outside and adjacent to the Magical Circle, usually 3 feet across. It is the designated locus where the evoked spirit is commanded to appear 'in a fair human shape,' often pointing towards the direction associated with the spirit.

Aleister Crowley's rationalist philosophical framework for understanding ceremonial magic. It posits that the invoked spirits are not external entities but represent psychological aspects or latent faculties within the magician's own brain or subconscious, and the rituals are elaborate methods of self-suggestion to activate and direct these internal forces.

Specific Hebrew, Greek, and Enochian names of God (e.g., ADONAI, TETRAGRAMMATON, EHYEH) and angels invoked during the conjurations. These names are considered to hold immense power, serving to establish the magician's authority, compel the spirits, and ensure their obedience.

practical_system.description: The Goetic system is a highly structured method for the evocation of 72 infernal spirits, aiming to compel them to visible appearance and obtain their services (e.g., knowledge, treasures, love, causing discord). It relies on precise ritual design, the potent use of divine names, specific astrological timings, and a hierarchy of commanding conjurations. The magician must prepare physical tools, consecrate sacred spaces, and maintain ritual purity to ensure control over the summoned entities.
tools: Magic Ring or Disc of Solomon
rituals: Preliminary Invocation of the Bornless One
Adoration at the Induing of the Vestments
The Conjuration to Call Forth Any of the Aforesaid Spirits (First, Second, and The Constraint)

relevant_quotes.text: The spirits of the Goetia are portions of the human brain. Their seals therefore represent (Mr. Spencer's projected cube) methods of stimulating or regulating those particular spots (through the eye).

MAGIC is the Highest, most Absolute, and most Divine Knowledge of Natural Philosophy, advanced in its works and wonderful operations by a right understanding of the inward and occult virtue of things; so that true Agents being applied to proper Patients, strange and admirable effects will thereby be produced.

I DO invocate, conjure, and command thee, O thou Spirit N., to appear and to show thself visibly unto me before this Circle in fair and comely shape, without any deformity or tortuosity; by the name and in the name IAH and VAU, which Adam heard and spake; and by the name of GOD, AGLA, which Lot heard and was saved with his family...

critical_analysis.relevance: This edition is a cornerstone text in modern Western Esotericism and ceremonial magic. It bridges traditional grimoire practice with a rational, psychological interpretation, profoundly influencing practitioners of Thelema, Chaos Magic, and other contemporary occult traditions. Crowley's commentary provides a framework for understanding magical operations not merely as superstitious rites, but as profound psychological processes for self-mastery and the activation of latent potential, making it continuously relevant for both practical magicians and academic scholars.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience includes practicing ceremonial magicians, advanced students of Western Esotericism, scholars of occult history and philosophy, and individuals interested in the psychological and self-transformative aspects of ritual magic.
